pages.text: Great Danes have two genes that affect how they look. These are the B Locus and D Locus. The B Locus determines whether a dog is black or fawn, while the D Locus can dilute them to blue. The D Locus only affects black dogs.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black coloration, while the 'b' allele creates brown, or fawn, coloration. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the fawn trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for fawn pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either fawn carriers or fawn puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The D Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'D' and the recessive 'd'. The 'D' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'd' allele is a dilute that creates pale, or blue, fur. Dogs with one copy of 'd' will carry the dilution trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for diluted pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'd' will always create either dilute carriers or blue puppies.
pages.title: D Locus
